DOC.brief_summary: Study Hypothesis: A virtual peer-to-peer support intervention will improve health outcomes and quality of life in adolescents with chronic pain.
DOC.brief_title: Virtual Peer-to-Peer (VP2P) Support Mentoring for Chronic Pain: A Pilot RCT
DOC.detailed_description: The aim of this project is to develop and examine the impact of a virtual peer support program on health outcomes and quality of life of adolescents with chronic pain using a waitlist randomized controlled trial. In addition to standard medical care, adolescents in the experimental group will receive a manualized peer mentorship program that will provide modeling and reinforcement by trained young adults aged 16-25 years who have learned to function successfully with their pain. Mentoring sessions consist of 10 sessions of 30-45 minute Skype calls over 8 weeks. Feasibility of the program will be measured in addition to quality of life, physical and emotional symptoms, pain coping, self-efficacy, social support, and self-management skills.
DOC.criteria: males and females 1218 years old diagnosed chronic pain condition (e.g., neuropathic pain, Complex Regional Pain Syndrome, chronic musculoskeletal pain, chronic daily headache, chronic widespread pain) able to speak and read English access to Internet connection, computer capable of using free Skype software willing and able to complete online measures. significant cognitive impairments major comorbid illnesses (i.e., psychiatric conditions) likely to influence HRQL assessment participating in peer support or selfmanagement interventions (e.g., WebMap).
